Dead by Daylight hat mir viele witzige Momente (auch Dank einigen Bugs) beschert, mich gefrustet, unterhalten, meine Nerven auf die Probe gestellt und vorallem schÃ¶ne Bekanntschaften in der Community gebracht.

Wer schnelles Gameplay in Kombination mit "Hide and Seek" mag, gerne levelt und ein PvP-Liebhaber ist, kann ich das Spiel nur weiterempfehlen.

Asymmetrical games are an untapped source of online potential. Dead by Daylight is by a longshot the best of the genre to date, beating all past and current competition, namely in bang for your buck fun, core gameplay mechanics and continued support from the devs. The main complaints I and my friends who I play with are all about balancing, which is something that has been (in my opinion) tuned well enough to award players for skill without too many curtches (but I have to admit, the survivor team does have a fair share of crutches compared the the killers few). A great Horror Game experience for one team, and a great Killer experience for the other. Dead By Daylight has become my most played game and one that I continue to want to come back to after every session. Highly recommend, don't be deterred by reviews focused on balance issues. Core Game is solid and with seemingly dedicated developers, it will continue to be.

Fun for a laugh, but the matchmaking, ranking, and frequent disconnects limit the replay and competitiveness factors.

Matchmaking: Appears to be mostly random. For example, as a rank 18 level 12 killer with a tier 1 perk, I was placed against rank 1 players with four tier 3 rare perks. Makes it feel super punishing as a new player.

Ranking: Anyone that accomplishes the bare minimum could attain and hold max rank with the major limitations being access to perks and addons, and less emphasis on skill. These need to be unlocked by points and unfortunately it seems to be points efficient even if you donâ€™t accomplish the primary objective of the match (aka you can still get a lot of points if you â€œloseâ€). Sometimes matches turn into points farming sessions instead of a survival thriller.

Disconnects: It felt like people were disconnecting from almost every game, so I started recording them. On average, over twenty games, a player disconnects once per game. I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s an issue with the game connectivity/bug or if itâ€™s just bad manners, but the game is clearly balanced around 4v1 and having players(s) DC makes the game less fun for everyone thatâ€™s left.

The ambience, artwork, and music are all great â€“ except for the occasional janky animation. The Huntress is wicked fun to play, and sneaking around as a survivor is intense. A lot of work has gone into making the game feel eerie, moody, and creepy, but itâ€™s too easy to have sessions reduced to mechanical points/rank farming, or for everyone to give up because the first survivor hooked rage quits.

Iâ€™ll come back to the game for sure if they implement harsher disconnect penalties, an actual ranking system ladder that lets me compare my skill to the rest of the player base (instead of just time played), and maybe some basic balance stuff that seems standard in other PvP games (like diminishing returns on abilities/mechanics like flashlight blinds and slug mode for both the survivors and killers).

Das Einzige, was mich persÃ¶nlich an Dead by Daylight nervt, ist das ewig lange Warten bis man Mitspieler gefunden hat, um eine Runde zu beginnen. Doch auch diese Kleinigkeit nehme ich gerne in Kauf, wobei sich die Wartezeit mittlerweile auch wieder reduziert hat.
